questions.text:
A 61-year-old postmenopausal female presents for her annual exam without complaints. You notice a white patchy area between the posterior forchette of the vagina and the anus. When questioned about this area, the patient denies any pruritis or irritation. You obtain a biopsy of this
area, and the pathology reveals well-defined inflammatory band consists predominantly of lymphocytes in the superficial connective tissue that involves the dermoepidermal junction. What is the first line treatment for this lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Clobetasol cream Ref: Read the text below Sol: 

• Lichen sclerosis is a benign vulvar lesion common among postmenopausal women and often asymptomatic. 

• The firstline treatment of lichen sclerosis is a high-potency topical steroid such as clobetasol. 

• It is important to remember that this lesion is associated with vulvar cancer and close surveillance should be maintained.

choices.text: The need to repeat the fetal scalp pH test in 20 minutes
The need for immediate cesarean section

questions.text: A patient in the active phase of labor is 5 cm dilated, and the fetal heart monitor shows decreased variability. The monitor shows a baseline fetal rate of 125 beats per minute (bpm), with occasional late decelerations. A fetal scalp pH of 7.22 is obtained. This situation indicates which of the following conditions or actions ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

The need to repeat the fetal scalp pH test in 20 minutes Ref: Read the
text below Sol: The fetal scalp blood pH : 

• The normal fetal scalp blood pH ranges between 7.25 to 7.35. 
• A pH value of less than 7.2 is an indication for urgent interference. 
• A fetal scalp pH of 7.20 to 7.24 is worrisome but is not indicative of severe distress, asphyxia or 
• metabolic acidosis in the fetus; there is no need for immediate cesarean section delivery. The scalp 
• pH measurement, however, must be repeated in 20 to 30 minutes. 
• A chorioamnionitis with a maternal temperature elevation would produce a fetal tachycardia of greater than 160 beats per minute (bpm).

choices.text: Reassure and follow up at the 30-month visit
Refer for a hearing evaluation and speech therapy
Recommend watching educational videos to improve speech

questions.text: A parent is concerned that their 24-month-old child is not yet combining two words. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Refer for a hearing evaluation and speech therapy

By 24 months, a child should be combining two words into phrases (e.g.,"want cookie"). Failure to do so is a red flag for speech delay, and hearing impairment should be ruled out. 

Early intervention with speech therapy is recommended. Delaying intervention 

(A) is inappropriate. Occupational therapy 

(C) may be needed for other concerns but is not the first step for speech delay. Watching videos 

(D) is not an effective intervention.

choices.text: Is caused by oedema of the subcutaneous layers of the scalp
Most commonly lies over the occipital bone
Does not vary in tension with crying

questions.text: Choose the most appropriate statement regarding findings shown in the given image :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 
Does not vary in tension with crying Ref.: Read the text below Sol :
Caphalhaematoma : 
Collection of blood in between the pericranium and the flat bone of the skull. 
Usually unilateral.
Lies over a parietal bone. 
It is due to rupture of a small emissary vein from the skull and may be associated with fracture of the skull bone. 
Caused generally by forceps delivery but may also be met with following a normal labour. 
Ventouse application does not increase the incidence of cephalhaematoma 
It is never present at birth but gradually develops after 12-24 hours.
It is circumscribed, soft, fluctuant, and incompressible. 
The swelling is limited by the suture lines of the skull as the pericranium is fixed to the margins of the bone. 
The blood is absorbed in 6-8 weeks leaving an entirely normal skull. Rarely, suppuration occurs. No active treatment is necessary. 
Prognosis is good.

questions.text: A deep vein thrombosis patient was started on an anticoagulant therapy. Next day, the patient presented with the features shown in the diagram below. Likely drug implicated for this adverse effect is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Warfarin
Explanation:
The patient likely developed an adverse effect related to warfarin therapy, given the context of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and anticoagulant use. One of the key adverse effects of warfarin is skin necrosis or purple toe syndrome, which is a known complication, particularly in the early days of treatment.

Warfarin works by inhibiting vitamin K-dependent clotting factors (II, VII, IX, X) and can lead to a hypercoagulable state initially (before the anticoagulant effect fully kicks in). This can cause thrombosis in small vessels, leading to skin necrosis.

This adverse effect typically occurs within the first few days of treatment and is more common in patients with protein C or S deficiency, as these proteins are natural anticoagulants, and their inhibition by warfarin can cause an increased risk of clot formation.

Why the other options are incorrect:
A. Heparin – Incorrect:

Heparin is a direct thrombin inhibitor that is commonly used in the hospital setting for DVT treatment. It can cause heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), but it does not commonly cause the type of skin necrosis or purple toe syndrome seen with warfarin. HIT can lead to thrombosis, but not the same cutaneous symptoms as warfarin.

B. Rivaroxaban – Incorrect:

Rivaroxaban is a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) that inhibits Factor Xa. While DOACs have their own risk of bleeding and thrombosis, they are not commonly associated with the same skin necrosis or purple toe syndrome seen with warfarin.

D. Dabigatran – Incorrect:

Dabigatran is another DOAC, this one inhibiting thrombin (Factor II). While it has anticoagulant effects, it is not associated with skin necrosis or the early hypercoagulable state seen with warfarin. Like rivaroxaban, it does not produce the same complications as warfarin.

choices.text: Round ligaments attached to the uterus posterior to the insertion of the fallopian tubes

questions.text: The uterus and adnexa have some relatively fixed anatomic characteristics that can be noted on pelvic examination or laparoscopic observation. Which of the following characteristics would you most likely find in a normal patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Retroflexion of the uterus 

• The cervix protrudes into the fornix of the vagina, and the ovaries are found cephalad to the cervix. 

• The round ligaments are attached to the uterus anterior to the attachment of the fallopian tubes. Retroflexion implies a sharp angle between
the cervix and the fundus of the uterus, which is bent posteriorly. 

• This is a less common position of the uterus, which can also, more commonly, be midposition or anteflexed. 

• These are all normal positions of the uterus. It is important to recognize which way the uterine body is flexed so that you do not perforate the lower uterine segment while sounding the uterus or dilating the cervix. 

• The uterus is normally mobile and if it is not, adhesions or tumor may be present. The cervix is normally palpated anterior to the rectum on rectal examination.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) has infertility of 1-year duration. Her menses occur at irregular intervals, and BBTs are monophasic. An endometrial biopsy shows endometrial hyperplasia with mild cytologic atypia. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Medroxyprogesterone acetate 
• This patient with PCOS is anovulatory, as confirmed by the absence of a biphasic shift in BBTs. 
• Acyclic estrogen production unopposed by progesterone stimulates endometrial proliferation, increasing the risk of developing endometrial hyperplasia and carcinoma. 
• In patients desiring to preserve fertility, high-dose protesting such as 10–20 mg of MPA is appropriate. A biopsy should be repeated in 3 to 6 months. 
• If the biopsy is then normal, she may need ovulation induction. The method of choice for this patient with PCOS is clomiphene citrate. 
• Intramuscular administration of hMGs is expensive and inconvenient and requires close monitoring.

questions.text: After taking antiemetic, patient develops torticollis. Which drug might be responsible for this:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The patient developed torticollis, a type of acute dystonic reaction, after taking an antiemetic. Metoclopramide, a dopamine D2 receptor antagonist, is well-known to cause extrapyramidal side effects including acute dystonia, oculogyric crisis, and torticollis, especially in young adults and children. These reactions usually occur within hours of administration and are reversible with anticholinergic drugs like benztropine or diphenhydramine.

Incorrect options:

Option (A): Promethazine – Can rarely cause dystonia, but primarily antihistaminic; less common than metoclopramide.

Option (C): Ondansetron – A 5-HT3 antagonist, not associated with extrapyramidal symptoms.

Option (D): Aprepitant – A NK1 receptor antagonist; not known to cause acute dystonic reactions.

questions.text: A patient presented with hyperkalemia. Which of the following drugs can decrease extracellular potassium levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Epinephrine
Explanation:
Epinephrine (adrenaline) is a catecholamine that can help lower extracellular potassium levels by promoting the movement of potassium from the extracellular space (blood) into the cells. It does this through:

β?-adrenergic receptor activation, which stimulates the Na?/K? ATPase pump.

This pump transports potassium into cells, reducing potassium concentration in the bloodstream.

This effect is particularly useful in the management of hyperkalemia, as it quickly shifts potassium into cells, helping to stabilize potassium levels.

Why the other options are incorrect:
A. Atropine – Incorrect:

Atropine is a muscarinic receptor antagonist that is used to treat bradycardia.

It does not have a direct effect on potassium levels and does not shift potassium into cells.

B. Lactic acid – Incorrect:

Lactic acid is associated with lactic acidosis, a condition in which potassium may actually increase in the extracellular space due to acidosis, not decrease.

D. Glucagon – Incorrect:

Glucagon mainly increases blood glucose levels by promoting glycogen breakdown in the liver.

While it has some effects on cardiac function, it does not have a direct mechanism to lower extracellular potassium levels.

choices.text: Drug B is less potent but equally efficacious as drug D
Drug C is less potent and more efficacious than drug A
Drug Dis more potent and more efficacious than drug B
Drug A is more potent and equally efficacious as drug B

questions.text: From the given image, find out the true statement.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Drug A is more potent and equally efficacious as drug B
Explanation:

Potency refers to the amount of a drug needed to produce a given effect, while efficacy refers to the maximum effect a drug can produce. On a dose-response curve (typically with dose on the x-axis and response on the y-axis), a more potent drug reaches the same effect at a lower dose, meaning it is shifted to the left. Equal efficacy means the drugs reach the same maximum response (plateau) on the y-axis.

From the image:

Drug A's curve lies to the left of Drug B, meaning Drug A is more potent (requires a lower dose to achieve the same effect).

Both Drug A and Drug B reach the same maximal response, indicating they are equally efficacious.
Thus, Option D is correct.

Why the other options are incorrect:
A. Drug B is less potent but equally efficacious as drug D – Incorrect:
If Drug D has a higher maximal response than Drug B, it is more efficacious, not equally efficacious. Also, potency comparison must show relative positions on the x-axis, which this option misrepresents.

B. Drug C is less potent and more efficacious than drug A – Incorrect:
If Drug C has a lower maximal response than Drug A, it is less efficacious, not more. Additionally, if it is shifted to the right of Drug A, it is less potent, but the efficacy part of the statement is incorrect.

C. Drug D is more potent and more efficacious than drug B – Incorrect:
If Drug D is not significantly to the left of Drug B, it may not be more potent. And if its maximal response is not higher, it's also not more efficacious. The statement may be partially true but is not fully correct based on the image.

questions.text: Maneuver shown in the Photograph is known as
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Marcieu-Smellie-Veit maneuver 

• Malar flexion and shoulder traction (modified Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique): 
• The baby is placed on the supinated left forearm(preferred) with the limbs hanging on either sides 
• The middle and the index fingers of the left hand areplaced over the malar bones on either sides) to maintainflexion of the head 
• The ring and little fingers of the pronated right handare placed on the child's right shoulder, the index finger placed on the left shoulder and the middle finger is placed on the suboccipital region 
• Now the traction is given in downward and backwarddirection till the nape of the neck is visible under thepubic arch 
• The assistant gives suprapubic pressure during the periodto maintain flexion

questions.text: A patient comes to you with breathlessness, dry cough with reduced exercise capacity. On X ray examination, diagnosis of pulmonary fibrosis is made. Which of the following drug can be used for the treatment of this condition:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Perfinidone

• Pirfenidone is a synthetic pyridone drug. 

• The FDA first approved pirfenidone alongside nintedanib as one of the first drugs to treat IPF.

• It is an antifibrotic agent with anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties that is used to treat idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, which is a chronic, progressive form of interstitial pneumonia.

• Mechanism of action is not yet fully understood, pirfenidone is proposed to primarily regulate tumor necrosis factor (TNF) pathways and modulate cellular oxidation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary mechanism leading to neonatal hypoglycaemia in preterm child
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Impaired hepatic glucose production

Newborns rely on glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis for glucose homeostasis. 

Preterm infants, SGA infants, and IDMs may have limited glycogen stores or impaired gluconeogenesis, leading to hypoglycemia.

choices.text: At the time of an amniocentesis

questions.text: A 25-year-old G1 P0 at 9 weeks' gestation presents for her initial prenatal visit. She has no medical or surgical history and has a certain LMP that is consistent with her examination. The patient has donated blood in the past and knows that she is Rh negative. In which of the following situations would the patient be cared for without being treated with RhoGAM?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Contractions at 34 weeks' gestation Ref: Read the text below Sol: 

•  Management of Rh-negative patients with RhoGAM has led to a marked reduction in women who have been sensitized to the Rh antigen. 

• The recommendations for treatment with RhoGAM include use anytime in the first two trimesters with vaginal bleeding or amniocentesis, at the beginning of the
third trimester at approximately 28 weeks' gestation, during the third trimester if there are signs of a fetal-maternal hemorrhage that is greater than can be negated by the 28-week dose of RhoGAM, and postpartum if the infant is Rh positive. 

• RhoGAM is not routinely given during preterm labor unless the patient has not yet received a dose in the pregnancy.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old G3 P2 woman presents with heavy, prolonged vaginal bleeding. She has no other complaints. Up until 8 months ago she had regular monthly menses which lasted 4 to 5 days. Over the past 8 months, her periods have become progressively heavy and a bit longer. The current
bleeding episode began 13 days ago. She has no other significant medical history. On physical exam she weighs 122 pounds and her blood pressure is 117/68. On pelvic exam she has a small amount of blood in the vaginal vault. Her uterus is normal size, nontender, and mobile. Her ovaries are not
palpable. The patient had a normal Pap smear 3 months ago and no history of abnormal Pap smears. On pelvic ultrasound, she has an 8-cm uterus with a normal myometrium and normal endometrial myometrial junction. The endometrium is 14 mm and there is a 2 cm × 1.2 cm lesion in the uterine
cavity. Her β- hCG,TSH, and endometrial biopsy are all normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Endometrial polyp 
• The lesion in this woman's uterus is most likely an endometrial polyp given the endometrial mass. 
• Endometrial polyps are typically benign masses that most commonly present in women over age 40. 
• They can cause heavy and/or prolonged bleeding similar to fibroids and adenomyosis. 
• The pelvic ultrasound showing a normal myometrium and normal endometrial myometrial junction make fibroids and adenomyosis much less likely. •
Endometrial hyperplasia and endometrial cancer can also present with abnormal bleeding and
endometrial mass. 
• However, this patient has none of the risk factors for endometrial cancer such as obesity, hypertension, or diabetes. 
• Dysfunctional uterine bleeding is a diagnosis of exclusion describing bleeding with no identifiable etiology. In this case, there is an identifiable cause of the patient's symptoms. 
• The most likely next step would be a sonohysterogram to better characterize the endometrial mass hysteroscopy to remove it.

questions.text: Correlate the findings shown in the image below and comment on the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Dysgerminoma
Ref.: Read the text below
Sol :
Dysgerminoma is malignant germ cell tumor. It arises from undifferentiated form of germ cells.
It is often associated with gonadal dysgenesis or androgen insensitivity syndrome or true hermaphroditism.

choices.text: Plasma concentration and half life doubles
Plasma concentration and half life remains unchanged

questions.text: First order kinetics if drug dose doubled then what happens:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

In first-order kinetics, the rate of drug elimination is proportional to its plasma concentration. Key features include:

Constant half-life (t½) regardless of dose.

Plasma concentration increases proportionally if the dose is doubled, but the half-life does not change.

Incorrect options:

Option (A): Half-life doubles – Incorrect; half-life in first-order kinetics is independent of dose.

Option (C): Plasma concentration and half-life doubles – Incorrect; only plasma concentration increases proportionally, half-life remains the same.

Option (D): Plasma concentration and half-life remains unchanged – Incorrect; plasma concentration increases with dose in first-order kinetics.

questions.text: A 23 year old nulliparous patient has history of regular cycles of 33 days since Menarche. She had her menses on 15th of january 2021. When is the expected date of Ovulation in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Ovulation typically occurs 14 days before the next expected menstrual period.

Given:

Cycle length = 33 days

Last menstrual period (LMP) = 15th January 2021

Expected next period = 15th January + 33 days = 17th February 2021

Ovulation date = 14 days before 17th February = 3rd February 2021 (rounding to the nearest day, 2nd February 2021).

Incorrect options:

Option (A): 29th January 2021 – Too early; would correspond to a 17-day luteal phase, which is unlikely.

Option (C): 7th February 2021 – Too late; closer to mid-luteal phase.

Option (D): 17th February 2021 – This is the expected next menses, not ovulation.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with sudden onset of lower abdominal pain. Pelvic examination reveals a normal sized uterus and normal appearing cervix and vagina. However, there is marked tenderness upon palpation of the left adnexal region. A transvaginal ultrasound demonstrates no intrauterine gestational sac, but there is a 2 cm left adnexal mass.. Which of the following is most useful procedure to perform at this point for the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Serum beta-HCG Ref:Read the text below Sol: 
• You should strongly suspect an ectopic pregnancy in this setting. 
• Complement levels are used to solve complex problems with autoimmune diseases, which are chronic in nature. 
• A routine urinalysis does not include a pregnancy test or a determination of HCG level. 
• Besides, this is not a 'STAT' test. The Pap smear is useful for screening for dysplasia or carcinoma and for some infections 
• The endometrial biopsy might be a next step with a positive HCG to help determine if the pregnancy is ectopic.

questions.text: Orphan Drug:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

An orphan drug is a medication developed specifically to treat rare diseases or conditions affecting a small percentage of the population. Because these diseases are rare, drug development is often not profitable, so governments may provide incentives, grants, or market exclusivity to encourage pharmaceutical companies to develop orphan drugs.

Incorrect options:

Option (B): Drug for free distribution – Incorrect; orphan drugs are not necessarily free.

Option (C): Drugs for cancer – Incorrect; while some cancer drugs can be orphan drugs, the term is not limited to cancer.

Option (D): Drugs which are rarely used – Incorrect; orphan drugs are defined by the rarity of the disease, not by frequency of use.

questions.text: Which of the following drug causes the effects on blood pressure and HR as shown in the figure
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation: The figure shows a significant increase in systolic, diastolic, and mean blood pressure, indicating a generalized vasoconstriction. Simultaneously, there is a decrease in heart rate, described as "Reflex bradycardia." This specific combination of effects is characteristic of Norepinephrine (Nor-epinephrine).

Let's analyze the effects of each option:

A. Epinephrine (Adrenaline): Epinephrine stimulates both alpha (α) and beta (β) adrenergic receptors. It causes vasoconstriction (α1) leading to increased systolic and mean blood pressure, but it also strongly stimulates β1 receptors in the heart, leading to increased heart rate and cardiac contractility. While it increases pulse pressure, the reflex bradycardia seen in the figure is less typical as its direct β1 effects would counteract it, or the reflex would be masked.

B. Norepinephrine (Nor-epinephrine): Norepinephrine primarily stimulates α1 receptors (causing potent vasoconstriction) and β1 receptors (in the heart). The strong α1-mediated vasoconstriction leads to a marked increase in systolic, diastolic, and mean arterial pressure. This significant rise in blood pressure then triggers a strong baroreceptor reflex. The baroreceptors sense the increased pressure and respond by increasing parasympathetic (vagal) tone to the heart, leading to reflex bradycardia (a decrease in heart rate) despite the direct β1 stimulation of the heart. This perfectly matches the figure.

C. Isoprenaline (Isoproterenol): Isoprenaline is a non-selective beta agonist, strongly stimulating β1 and β2 receptors. It causes vasodilation (β2), leading to a decrease in diastolic blood pressure and often a slight decrease in mean arterial pressure. It strongly increases heart rate and cardiac contractility (β1). This is the opposite of what is shown in the figure for blood pressure and heart rate.

D. Dopamine: Dopamine's effects are dose-dependent. At low doses, it stimulates D1 receptors causing renal and mesenteric vasodilation. At moderate doses, it stimulates β1 receptors, increasing heart rate and contractility. At high doses, it stimulates α1 receptors, causing vasoconstriction. While it can increase blood pressure at high doses, it usually increases heart rate directly or reflexively, and the combined pattern shown (marked increase in all pressures with reflex bradycardia) is not its primary or most characteristic effect compared to norepinephrine.

questions.text: A 27-year-old G1 P0 at 40 weeks' gestation presents to labor and delivery with contractions every 6 to 8 minutes.Of the following findings, which is the most worrisome on the fetal heart tracing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Repetitive late decelerations, absent variability 
• Fetal heart rates are evaluated, paying attention to baseline rate, variability, accelerations, and decelerations. The baseline rate should be between 110 and 160 bpm. 
• Minimal and absent variability are worrisome for hypoxia and acidemia of the fetus, with absent variability being worse than minimal. Three types
of decelerations have been described—early, variable, and late. 
• Early decelerations begin and end with contractions and are thought to be a result of fetal head compression. 
• Variable decelerations are sharp drops in the fetal heart rate with quick return to baseline and can be either isolated or correlated with contractions; these are believed to result from compression of the umbilical cord. Late decelerations begin after the contraction has begun and end after it has ended. These are usually
shallow and can be quite subtle and difficult to detect. 
• Late decelerations are correlated with decreased placental perfusion that can be secondary to inadequate blood flow to

questions.text: A boy is planning to travel by bus. Which of the following drug can be used to prevent motion sickness in this person?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Promethazine
Explanation:
Promethazine is an antihistamine that is commonly used to prevent motion sickness. It works by blocking histamine receptors (H? receptors) in the brain, which are involved in the sensation of nausea and vomiting. Promethazine has anticholinergic properties as well, which help to prevent the nausea and dizziness associated with motion sickness.

Promethazine is effective in preventing and treating motion sickness, and is typically used before travel to minimize symptoms.

Why the other options are incorrect:
B. Cetirizine – Incorrect:

Cetirizine is a second-generation antihistamine, commonly used for allergic reactions (like hay fever, urticaria) due to its non-sedating properties. While it can block histamine, it is not specifically used for motion sickness, as it doesn't have the same sedative or anticholinergic effects needed for preventing nausea.

C. Loratadine – Incorrect:

Loratadine is also a second-generation antihistamine, which is non-sedating and typically used for allergic conditions. Like cetirizine, it does not have the necessary properties to prevent motion sickness, as it lacks the anticholinergic effect necessary to address the nausea and dizziness caused by motion.

D. Fexofenadine – Incorrect:

Fexofenadine is another second-generation antihistamine that is primarily used to treat allergic symptoms, such as rhinoconjunctivitis and urticaria. Similar to cetirizine and loratadine, it does not have sufficient anticholinergic properties to effectively treat or prevent motion sickness.

choices.text: Deficiency of clotting factors due to vitamin C-dependent synthesis
Increased capillary fragility due to defective collagen formation
Suppression of platelet production in the bone marrow

questions.text: Which of the following best explains why scurvy leads to easy bruising and delayed wound healing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Increased capillary fragility due to defective collagen formation Vitamin C is essential for collagen synthesis, and its deficiency weakens blood vessel walls, leading to capillary fragility, easy bruising, and poor wound healing. 

Unlike vitamin K deficiency, scurvy does not impair clotting factor production.

choices.text: Biopsy of the cyst and insertion of Word catheter

questions.text: 49-year-old woman presents complaining of vulvar pain that increases with ambulation and intercourse. She also notes a lump on her right labia that has increased in size over the past 48 hours and is quite painful. The patient has had these same symptoms in the past. On examination she has a 5-cm tender cyst on the medial aspect of her right labia, with a surrounding erythema of the labia that extends 1 to 2 cm away. What would be your first step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Incision and Drainage Ref: Read the text below Sol: 

• First step incision and drainage followed by biopsy of the cyst wall 

• If malignancy was present, total excision would be indicated. In addition to biopsy and I&D with Word catheter placement, the patient should do sitz
baths three to four times a day as well. If there is surrounding cellulitis as in this case, antibiotics to cover skin flora are used as well. If the patient merely had an enlarged Bartholin cyst, sitz baths alone could be considered. With an abscess or cyst of this size, needle drainage would not be used because the cavity of the cyst would continue to be or become infected. 

• If the Word catheter failed to treat the Bartholin cyst, marsupialization could then be attempted.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant with cholestasis undergoes a liver biopsy, revealing bile duct paucity. Which syndrome is most commonly associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Alagille syndrome 

Alagille syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by JAG1 or NOTCH2 mutations, leading to bile duct paucity, cardiac
anomalies (pulmonary stenosis), vertebral defects, and characteristic facies. Biliary atresia shows ductal proliferation, while alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency shows PAS-positive, diastase-resistant inclusions in hepatocytes.

questions.text: 45 year woman present s with irregular bleeding since last 1 year, she bleeds heavy every 2-3 months. Endometrial biopsy was done for her which shows Swiss cheese pattern of endometrium. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Metropathia haemorrhagica Sol:

Metropathia Haemorrhagica or 'Schroeder's disease'from 'cystic glandular hyperplasia'. 
• Metropathia Haemorrhagica or 'Schroeder's disease' is a type of anovulatory dysfunctional uterine bleeding characterized by 'cystic glandular hyperplasia'. 
• Glandular hyperplasia with cystic dilatation of a few glands of variable sizes gives the endometrium a characteristic Swiss Cheese Appearance.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of doxycycline is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Protein synthesis inhibitor

Doxycycline is a tetracycline, acts via inhibiting the protein synthesis. It binds to 30S ribosome and then inhibits binding of aminoacyl t-RNA to A-site of m-RNA ribosome complex.

questions.text: Which of the following APGAR score interpretations is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

The APGAR score at 1 minute is used to predict long-term neurological sequel 

The APGAR score is designed to assess the newborn’s immediate post-birth condition and is not a predictor of long-term health outcomes. 

While a lower score at 1 minute can indicate distress, the score at 5 minutes is more predictive of the infant’s recovery. 

The score helps guide immediate interventions but not future health outcomes.

questions.text:
SGLT-2 inhibitors are recently used for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Which of the following are the rare but serious side effects? 

 A. Ketoacidosis  

B. Fournier gangrene  

C. Urosepsis  

D. Angioedema
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

SGLT-2 inhibitors are a class of oral antidiabetic drugs that reduce blood glucose by inhibiting renal glucose reabsorption in the proximal tubules. While generally safe, they are associated with rare but serious side effects, including:

  • A: Euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) – Can occur even with near-normal glucose levels.

  • B: Urinary tract infections (UTIs) and genital mycotic infections – Due to increased glycosuria.

  • C: Acute kidney injury – Rare but reported, especially in volume-depleted patients.

  • D: Fractures and amputations – Observed with some SGLT-2 inhibitors (e.g., canagliflozin).

questions.text: Primigravida at 34 weeks comes to antenatal OPD for a routine check up, on examination her blood pressure is 150/100 mmhg, urine dipstick shows 1+, she has no complaints. Her previous antenatal check ups were normal. All the following are a part of her management except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

She should be started on antihypertensives Ref: Read the text below
Sol:- 
• This patient is a case non severe pre eclampsia, she needs an in patient evauation and complete preeclampsia work up. 
• The minimum lab investigations should include platelet count , serum creatinine, liver enzymes and fundus examination and they should be at least repeated once a
week. Any deterioration will need more frequent follow up. 
• Fetal monitoring is an essential part of her management and the NST along with amniotic fluid should be done at least twice a week. Daily fetal movement count should be done .  
• Antihypertensives as per the latest recommendations have no role in non severe preeclampsia as it does not alter the disease process and does not diminish
perinatal morbidity and mortality. 
• Sodium restriction and diuretics have no role in routine therapy.

questions.text: Which anti-migraine drug should be avoided in a patient of bronchial asthma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Propranolol, a non-selective beta-blocker, should be avoided in patients with bronchial asthma because it can block β2-adrenergic receptors in the airways, leading to bronchoconstriction and potentially precipitating asthma attacks. Although it is effective for migraine prophylaxis, its use is contraindicated in reactive airway diseases.

Incorrect options:

Option (A): Acetaminophen – Safe in asthma; commonly used for pain relief.

Option (B): Sumatriptan – A 5-HT1B/1D agonist used for acute migraine; generally safe in asthma, though caution in patients with cardiovascular disease.

Option (D): Lasmiditan – A 5-HT1F receptor agonist for acute migraine attacks; does not affect bronchial tone and is safe in asthma.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a typical clinical feature of congenital hypothyroidism in a newborn?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Increased muscle tone Congenital hypothyroidism is associated with hypotonia (decreased muscle tone), not increased muscle tone. Other typical signs include a large anterior fontanelle, prolonged jaundice, constipation, macroglossia, umbilical hernia, and poor feeding.

questions.text: Which of the following is TRUE regarding the long-term prognosis of PSGN?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Most children recover completely without residual kidney damage

Children have an excellent prognosis, with nearly complete recovery in 90-95% of cases. 

However, adults have a higher risk of developing chronic kidney disease (CKD). Recurrence of PSGN is rare, even with repeat streptococcal infections. 

End-stage renal disease (ESRD) is very uncommon in children but may occur in older adults or those with underlying kidney disease.

questions.text: The spiegelberg’s criteria in the diagnosis of ovarian pregnancy are all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The gestation sac is connected with infundibulopelvic ligament The Spiegelberg criteria are four criteria used to identify ovarian ectopic pregnancies named after Otto Spiegelberg. 

Four criteria for differentiating ovarian from other ectopic pregnancies: 
1. The gestational sac is located in the region of the ovary. 
2. The ectopic pregnancy is attached to the uterus by the ovarian ligament.  
3. Ovarian tissue in the wall of the gestational sac is proved histologically. 
4. The tube on the involved side is intact.

questions.text: A neonate with TGA and an intact ventricular septum undergoes echocardiography. Which finding is most consistent with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Aorta anterior and to the right of the pulmonary artery 

In D-TGA, the great arteries are abnormally transposed, with the aorta positioned anterior and to the right of the pulmonary artery, originating from the right ventricle. In contrast, in normal anatomy, the pulmonary artery is anterior to the aorta.

questions.text: Drug of choice in facial nerve palsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The drug of choice for idiopathic facial nerve palsy (Bell’s palsy) is prednisolone, a corticosteroid. Corticosteroids reduce inflammation and edema of the facial nerve within the narrow bony canal, improving the chances of full functional recovery.

Early initiation (within 72 hours of symptom onset) is crucial for optimal outcomes.

Incorrect options:

Option (A): Acyclovir – May be used adjunctively if viral etiology (e.g., herpes simplex) is suspected, but not first-line.

Option (B): Ceftriaxone – An antibiotic; not indicated for idiopathic facial nerve palsy.

Option (D): Naproxen – NSAID; may reduce pain but does not address nerve inflammation or recovery.
